Treatment Principle: Subdue Liver Yang, Extinguish Wind, Nourish Liver Yin
Primary Acupuncture Points: GB20, LV3, LI4, Taiyang (EX-HN5), GB8, LV2, KI3
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 2-3x per week for 4-6 weeks, then weekly maintenance
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Tian Ma Gou Teng Yin (天麻钩藤饮)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Face (Front View), Head & Neck (Side View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Apply gentle pressure to Taiyang, GB20. Avoid scalp needling if severe. Consider auricular points for acute relief.

Treatment Principle: Extinguish Wind, Move Blood, Clear Liver-Gallbladder
Primary Acupuncture Points: GB20, LV3, SJ5, GB43, BL2, ST8, GB41, PC6
Treatment Frequency & Duration: Acute: daily for 3-5 days; Preventive: 2x per week for 8 weeks
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Chuan Xiong Cha Tiao San (川芎茶调散) + Tian Ma Gou Teng Yin (天麻钩藤饮)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Face (Front View), Head & Neck (Side View), Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Treat during pain-free intervals. Map trigger points. Use distal points (LV3, GB43) for acute phase.

Treatment Principle: Release Tai Yang, Relax muscles, Move Qi and Blood
Primary Acupuncture Points: GB20, Taiyang (EX-HN5), BL10, GV20, LI4, SJ5, GB21
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Xiao Yao San (逍遥散) if stress-related
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Neck (Side View), Back & Spine (Back View), Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Add cupping to GB21, upper back. Teach self-massage of Taiyang and GB20.

Condition / Diagnosis: Lower Back Pain - Kidney Yang Deficiency
Treatment Principle: Tonify Kidney Yang, Warm meridians, Strengthen lumbar
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL23, BL52, GV4 (Mingmen), KI3, CV4, BL40, GB34
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 2-3x per week for 8-10 weeks, with moxa
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Jin Gui Shen Qi Wan (金匮肾气丸) or You Gui Wan (右归丸)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Back & Spine (Back View), Leg (Back View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Apply moxa to BL23, GV4 for 15-20 min. Avoid deep needling in acute phase. Consider TDP lamp.

Treatment Principle: Invigorate Blood, Remove stasis, Stop pain
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL25, BL40, BL60, GB34, local Ashi points, SP10, LV3
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Shu Jing Huo Xue Tang (舒筋活血汤) or Du Huo Ji Sheng Tang (独活寄生汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Back & Spine (Back View), Leg (Back View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Use cupping and gua sha on Bladder meridian. Avoid excessive manipulation initially.

Treatment Principle: Expel Wind-Cold-Damp, Warm and unblock channels
Primary Acupuncture Points: GB20, BL10, SI3, GV14, GB21, LI4, BL60
Treatment Frequency & Duration: Acute: 3x per week for 2 weeks; Chronic: 2x per week for 6 weeks
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Ge Gen Tang (葛根汤) or Juan Bi Tang (蠲痹汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Neck (Side View), Back & Spine (Back View), Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Apply moxa or TDP lamp to GB20, GB21. Teach neck exercises post-treatment.

Treatment Principle: Move Qi and Blood, Open channels, Reduce inflammation
Primary Acupuncture Points: LI15, SJ14, SI9, GB21, LI11, LI4, GB34, local Ashi
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Shu Jing Huo Xue Tang (舒筋活血汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View), Back & Spine (Back View), Hand (Palm View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Combine with gentle ROM exercises. Use surrounding points if too tender. Consider electrical stimulation.

Treatment Principle: Dispel Wind-Damp, Strengthen Spleen and Kidney, Nourish Liver
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST35, ST36, SP9, SP10, GB34, local Xiyan (EX-LE5), BL40
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Du Huo Ji Sheng Tang (独活寄生汤) or Juan Bi Tang (蠲痹汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg & Thigh (Front View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Leg (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Avoid needling during acute inflammation. Use surrounding points and moxa. Teach strengthening exercises.

Treatment Principle: Move local Qi and Blood, Reduce inflammation, Relax tendons
Primary Acupuncture Points: LI11, LI10, SJ5, LI4, local Ashi points, GB34
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Shu Jing Huo Xue Tang (舒筋活血汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View), Hand (Palm View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Needle around inflamed area, not directly. Consider electro-acupuncture. Advise rest and ice.

Treatment Principle: Open channels, Reduce swelling, Move Qi and Blood
Primary Acupuncture Points: PC7, PC6, SJ5, LI4, SI3, local Ashi points
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Shu Jing Huo Xue Tang (舒筋活血汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Hand (Palm View), Pulse Point (Wrist Closeup)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Needle proximal and distal to affected area. Teach wrist stretches. Consider splinting at night.

Treatment Principle: Move Qi and Blood in channels, Relax muscles, Tonify Kidney
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL40, BL60, GB30, GB34, GB39, BL23, BL25, local Ashi
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Du Huo Ji Sheng Tang (独活寄生汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Back & Spine (Back View), Leg (Back View), Leg & Thigh (Front View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Combine with cupping on Bladder meridian. Avoid aggravating positions. Teach stretches.

Treatment Principle: Move Blood, Reduce swelling, Promote healing
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL60, KI3, GB40, ST41, local Ashi points, SP6
Treatment Frequency & Duration: Acute: daily for 5-7 days; Chronic: 2x per week for 4 weeks
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Die Da Wan (跌打丸) - topical and internal
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Back View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Foot (Sole/Bottom View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Ice and elevate first 48 hours. Needle distal points initially. Add moxa once acute phase passes.

Treatment Principle: Relax local muscles, Move Qi, Clear Stomach Heat if present
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST6, ST7, SI18, SI19, LI4, ST44, GB20
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Xiao Yao San (逍遥散) if stress-related; Qing Wei San (清胃散) if Heat
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Face (Front View), Head & Neck (Side View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Gentle needling around jaw. Teach jaw relaxation exercises. Consider stress management.

Treatment Principle: Soothe Liver, Move Qi, Harmonize Shao Yang
Primary Acupuncture Points: LV14, LV3, GB34, GB41, PC6, SJ6
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Xiao Yao San (逍遥散) or Chai Hu Shu Gan San (柴胡疏肝散)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Avoid deep needling in rib area. Focus on distal points. Address emotional factors.

Treatment Principle: Move local Qi and Blood, Relax tendons, Tonify Kidney
Primary Acupuncture Points: KI3, BL60, KI1, local Ashi points, GB34, BL40
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Du Huo Ji Sheng Tang (独活寄生汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Foot (Sole/Bottom View), Leg (Back View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Needle around heel, not into inflamed fascia. Use moxa on KI3. Recommend supportive footwear.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Qi and Blood, Move circulation, Calm Shen
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, LI4, GV20, HT7, PC6, tender Ashi points
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Gui Pi Tang (归脾汤) or Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang (补中益气汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Master Template (Full Body Fallback)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Gentle needling. Map and treat tender points rotationally. Emphasize lifestyle and stress management.

Treatment Principle: Nourish Blood, Move Qi, Open channels, Tonify Liver-Kidney
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, LV3, GB34, BL17, BL18, KI3, local points
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Si Wu Tang (四物汤) + modifications
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg & Thigh (Front View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Patient, consistent treatment. May require electro-stimulation. Monitor for medical causes.

Treatment Principle: Move Blood, Reduce swelling, Promote healing, Manage pain
Primary Acupuncture Points: Local Ashi points around scar, LI4, SP10, GB34, ST36
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 2-3x per week starting 2 weeks post-op for 6-8 weeks
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Xue Fu Zhu Yu Tang (血府逐瘀汤) once cleared by surgeon
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Area-specific per surgery location
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Coordinate with surgeon. Avoid direct needling of surgical site initially. Use distal points first.

Treatment Principle: Move Qi and Blood, Nourish Liver-Kidney, Dispel Wind-Damp
Primary Acupuncture Points: Local joint points, ST36, SP6, GB34, BL23, KI3
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Du Huo Ji Sheng Tang (独活寄生汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Specific to affected joints
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Manage expectations - symptom management not cure. Use moxa for cold-type. Gentle exercise important.

Treatment Principle: Move Qi and Blood, Extinguish Wind, Stop pain
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST6, ST7, LI4, ST36, GB20, branch-specific points
Treatment Frequency & Duration: Acute: 3x per week for 4 weeks; Maintenance: weekly
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Xiao Feng San (消风散) + modifications
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Face (Front View), Head & Neck (Side View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Very gentle needling away from trigger zones. May require medication coordination. Stress management crucial.

Treatment Principle: Soothe Liver, Strengthen Spleen, Harmonize intestines
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST25, ST36, SP6, LV3, LV14, PC6, CV12
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Tong Xie Yao Fang (痛泻要方) or Xiao Yao San (逍遥散)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Address stress/emotional factors. Dietary counseling essential. Combine with lifestyle modification.

Treatment Principle: Clear Heat, Moisten intestines, Promote bowel movement

Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Ma Zi Ren Wan (麻子仁丸)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg & Thigh (Front View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Increase fiber and water intake. Avoid excessive Heat-clearing if elderly or deficient.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Qi, Strengthen Spleen, Promote peristalsis
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, CV12, CV6, ST25, BL20, BL21
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang (补中益气汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Add moxa to CV6. Emphasize gentle exercise. Dietary support for Spleen Qi.

Treatment Principle: Harmonize Stomach, Descend rebellious Qi, Clear Heat
Primary Acupuncture Points: CV12, ST36, PC6, CV17, ST21, BL21
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Ban Xia Xie Xin Tang (半夏泻心汤) or Zuo Jin Wan (左金丸)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Lifestyle changes crucial: no late eating, elevate head, reduce stress. Coordinate with medical care.

Treatment Principle: Harmonize Stomach, Descend Qi, Stop nausea
Primary Acupuncture Points: PC6, CV12, ST36, SP4, CV17

Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Xiao Ban Xia Tang (小半夏汤) or Xuan Fu Dai Zhe Tang (旋覆代赭汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: PC6 very effective for acute nausea. Consider wrist bands for ongoing support. Rule out serious causes.

Condition / Diagnosis: Bloating - Spleen Qi Deficiency with Dampness
Treatment Principle: Tonify Spleen, Resolve Dampness, Move Qi
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, SP9, CV12, ST25, BL20, PC6
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Shen Ling Bai Zhu San (参苓白术散)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Dietary changes key: warm, cooked foods. Avoid raw, cold, greasy. Add moxa to CV12, ST36.

Treatment Principle: Warm and Tonify Spleen Yang, Stop diarrhea, Strengthen digestion
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, CV12, CV6, BL20, BL25, ST25 (all with moxa)
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Fu Zi Li Zhong Wan (附子理中丸) or Si Shen Wan (四神丸)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Heavy moxa essential. Avoid cold foods/drinks. Rule out infection. May require prolonged treatment.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Spleen-Kidney, Move Blood, Reduce inflammation
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, ST25, ST37, CV12, CV6, BL20, BL23
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Herbs individualized; commonly: Si Jun Zi Tang (四君子汤) + modifications
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Supportive care only, not curative. Coordinate with gastroenterologist. Focus on symptom management.

Treatment Principle: Clear Damp-Heat, Cool Blood, Tonify Spleen, Stop bleeding if present
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST25, ST37, SP6, SP10, LI11, ST36, CV12
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Bai Tou Weng Tang (白头翁汤) for active; tonifying formulas for remission
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Medical coordination essential. Address in remission periods. Stress management important.

Condition / Diagnosis: Loss of Appetite - Spleen Qi Deficiency
Treatment Principle: Tonify Spleen Qi, Harmonize Stomach, Increase appetite
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, CV12, PC6, SP6, BL20, BL21
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Si Jun Zi Tang (四君子汤) or Xiang Sha Liu Jun Zi Tang (香砂六君子汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Small frequent meals. Warm cooked foods. Address underlying causes. May need moxa.

Treatment Principle: Promote digestion, Move Qi, Resolve accumulation
Primary Acupuncture Points: CV12, ST36, PC6, ST25, ST44
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Bao He Wan (保和丸)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg & Thigh (Front View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Light diet for 24-48 hours. Avoid overeating. Teach mindful eating practices.

Treatment Principle: Nourish Stomach Yin, Clear deficiency Heat, Harmonize
Primary Acupuncture Points: CV12, ST36, SP6, KI3, PC6, BL21
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Yi Wei Tang (益胃汤) or Mai Men Dong Tang (麦门冬汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Cooling, moistening foods. Avoid spicy, fried, alcohol. Stress reduction. Medical coordination if H. pylori.

Treatment Principle: Harmonize Stomach, Clear Heat, Move Qi, Stop pain
Primary Acupuncture Points: CV12, ST36, PC6, SP4, CV10, BL21
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 2x per week as adjunct to medical treatment
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Under medical supervision; commonly: Huang Qi Jian Zhong Tang (黄芪建中汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Medical coordination mandatory. Avoid NSAIDs. Stress management. Dietary modifications.

Treatment Principle: Clear Damp-Heat, Move Blood, Stop bleeding, Tonify Spleen
Primary Acupuncture Points: GV1, BL57, SP6, SP10, ST25, LI11, GV20
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Huai Hua San (槐花散) + topical formulas
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Back View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Increase fiber, water. Sitz baths. Avoid prolonged sitting. GV1 can be needled with patient in knee-chest position.

Treatment Principle: Harmonize Stomach, Descend Qi, Stop hiccups
Primary Acupuncture Points: CV12, PC6, CV17, BL17, ST36
Treatment Frequency & Duration: As needed for acute; 2x per week if chronic
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Ding Xiang Shi Di Tang (丁香柿蒂汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: PC6 often very effective. For intractable hiccups, consider medical evaluation.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Kidney, Grasp Qi, Descend Lung Qi
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL13, BL23, CV17, LU7, LU1, KI3, CV6, DingChuan (EX-B1)
Treatment Frequency & Duration: Prevention: 2x per week for 12+ weeks; Acute: coordinate with medical care
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Su Zi Jiang Qi Tang (苏子降气汤) or Jin Gui Shen Qi Wan (金匮肾气丸)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Back & Spine (Back View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Preventive treatment between attacks. Acute asthma requires medical care. Apply moxa to BL23, CV6. Avoid triggers.

Treatment Principle: Nourish Lung Yin, Moisten Dryness, Stop cough
Primary Acupuncture Points: LU5, LU7, LU9, KI3, KI6, CV17, BL13
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Bai He Gu Jin Tang (百合固金汤) or Sha Shen Mai Men Dong Tang (沙参麦门冬汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Moistening diet: pears, honey, avoid spicy/dry foods. Rule out serious pathology. May take weeks to resolve.

Treatment Principle: Release exterior, Expel Wind-Cold, Warm lungs
Primary Acupuncture Points: LU7, LI4, GB20, BL12, GV14
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Gui Zhi Tang (桂枝汤) or Ma Huang Tang (麻黄汤) if severe
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Neck (Side View), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Treat at first sign. Keep warm. Rest. Hot ginger tea. Cupping on upper back effective.

Treatment Principle: Release exterior, Clear Heat, Expel Wind
Primary Acupuncture Points: LI4, LU11, LI11, GV14, GB20, LU7
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Yin Qiao San (银翘散) or Sang Ju Yin (桑菊饮)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Neck (Side View), Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Light diet. Avoid warming foods/spices. Rest. Peppermint tea. LU11 bleed technique if sore throat.

Treatment Principle: Resolve Phlegm, Strengthen Lung and Spleen, Stop cough
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL13, ST40, CV17, LU5, LU1, ST36, SP6, CV22
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Er Chen Tang (二陈汤) + modifications based on pattern
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Back & Spine (Back View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg & Thigh (Front View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Smoking cessation essential. Avoid cold/damp exposure. Breathing exercises. May need prolonged treatment.

Treatment Principle: Release exterior, Dispel Wind, Strengthen Wei Qi, Clear nose
Primary Acupuncture Points: LI20, Yintang (EX-HN3), Bitong (EX-HN8), LI4, LU7, ST36, GV23
Treatment Frequency & Duration: Acute: 2-3x per week during flare; Preventive: weekly for 8-12 weeks before season
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Yu Ping Feng San (玉屏风散) for prevention; Cang Er Zi San (苍耳子散) acute
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Face (Front View), Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Start preventive treatment 6-8 weeks before allergy season. Avoid triggers. Consider dietary changes.

Treatment Principle: Clear Heat, Resolve Dampness, Open orifices
Primary Acupuncture Points: LI20, Bitong (EX-HN8), Yintang (EX-HN3), LI4, ST40, LI11
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Cang Er Zi San (苍耳子散) + modifications
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Face (Front View), Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Steam inhalation. Avoid dairy. Rule out bacterial infection needing antibiotics. Nasal irrigation helpful.

Condition / Diagnosis: Shortness of Breath - Lung Qi Deficiency
Treatment Principle: Tonify Lung Qi, Strengthen respiration, Tonify Kidney
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL13, LU9, CV17, ST36, KI3, CV6, BL23
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Bu Fei Tang (补肺汤) or Yu Ping Feng San (玉屏风散)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Back & Spine (Back View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Rule out serious cardiopulmonary disease. Breathing exercises. Gentle exercise. Moxa to CV6, BL13.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Lung and Kidney, Resolve Phlegm, Support breathing
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL13, BL23, CV17, LU1, ST40, ST36, KI3, DingChuan (EX-B1)
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Bu Fei Tang (补肺汤) + individualized modifications
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Back & Spine (Back View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Supportive care only. Medical management essential. Pulmonary rehabilitation. Smoking cessation. Breathing techniques.

Treatment Principle: Nourish Lung Yin, Open throat, Benefit voice
Primary Acupuncture Points: LU7, LU10, KI6, CV22, CV23, LI4
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Yang Yin Qing Fei Tang (养阴清肺汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Voice rest essential. Warm water. Avoid whispering (strains more). Rule out structural pathology. Humidify air.

Treatment Principle: Subdue Liver Yang, Nourish Liver Yin, Calm Spirit
Primary Acupuncture Points: LV3, GB20, LI4, KI3, GV20, LV2, ST36
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 2x per week for 12+ weeks as adjunct to medication
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Tian Ma Gou Teng Yin (天麻钩藤饮)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Neck (Side View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Monitor BP closely. Medication adjustment with MD only. Lifestyle: reduce salt, stress management, exercise.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Heart Qi and Blood, Calm Shen
Primary Acupuncture Points: HT7, PC6, BL15, ST36, SP6, CV17, CV14
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Gui Pi Tang (归脾汤) or Zhi Gan Cao Tang (炙甘草汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Rule out arrhythmia requiring medical care. Reduce caffeine/stimulants. Sleep hygiene. Stress reduction.

Treatment Principle: Regulate Heart Qi, Calm Shen, Harmonize rhythm
Primary Acupuncture Points: HT7, PC6, BL15, CV17, ST36, SP6
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 1-2x per week as adjunct to medical management
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Individualized; commonly: Zhi Gan Cao Tang (炙甘草汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Medical management essential. Acupuncture as supportive only. Monitor for adverse events. Stress management key.

Condition / Diagnosis: Poor Circulation - Qi and Blood Stagnation
Treatment Principle: Move Qi and Blood, Warm channels, Invigorate circulation
Primary Acupuncture Points: SP10, SP6, LV3, ST36, PC6, local area points
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Dang Gui Si Ni Tang (当归四逆汤) or Xue Fu Zhu Yu Tang (血府逐瘀汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Hand (Palm View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Exercise crucial. Avoid smoking. Warm clothing in cold. Consider compression if venous insufficiency.

Treatment Principle: Warm Yang, Move Qi and Blood, Open channels
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, LI4, KI3, CV4, local hand/foot points
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 2x per week for 8-12 weeks with moxa
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Dang Gui Si Ni Tang (当归四逆汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Hand (Palm View), Foot (Sole/Bottom View), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Heavy moxa to affected areas and CV4. Avoid cold exposure. Stress management. Rule out autoimmune causes.

Treatment Principle: Invigorate Blood, Strengthen Spleen, Resolve stasis
Primary Acupuncture Points: SP10, SP6, SP9, ST36, local points along varicosities, BL40
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Xue Fu Zhu Yu Tang (血府逐瘀汤) + Bu Yang Huan Wu Tang (补阳还五汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg & Thigh (Front View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Leg (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Compression stockings. Elevate legs. Exercise. Weight management. Avoid prolonged standing. Needle carefully around veins.

Treatment Principle: Move Qi, Invigorate Blood, Open chest, Calm Shen
Primary Acupuncture Points: PC6, CV17, HT7, BL15, BL17, ST36
Treatment Frequency & Duration: Only as adjunct to medical management
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Under medical supervision; often: Gua Lou Xie Bai Ban Xia Tang (瓜蒌薤白半夏汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Medical coordination mandatory. Emergency protocols in place. Monitor closely. Not primary treatment for angina.

Treatment Principle: Move Blood, Resolve stasis, Tonify Spleen, Reduce swelling
Primary Acupuncture Points: SP9, SP6, ST36, SP10, BL40, local edema points
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Bu Yang Huan Wu Tang (补阳还五汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg & Thigh (Front View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Leg (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Compression essential. Elevate legs. Exercise. Skin care to prevent ulcers. May require long-term treatment.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Heart and Spleen, Nourish Blood, Calm Shen
Primary Acupuncture Points: HT7, SP6, ST36, Anmian (EX-HN22), BL15, BL20, PC6
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Gui Pi Tang (归脾汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Head & Neck (Side View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Sleep hygiene essential. Regular schedule. Avoid screens before bed. Relaxation techniques. May need 8-12 weeks.

Treatment Principle: Soothe Liver, Move Qi, Calm Shen

Treatment Principle: Soothe Liver, Move Qi, Uplift Spirit

Treatment Principle: Tonify Heart and Spleen, Nourish Blood, Calm Shen

Treatment Principle: Calm Shen, Anchor Yang, Regulate Heart

Treatment Principle: Calm Shen, Anchor Spirit, Regulate Qi and Blood

Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Head & Face (Front View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Trauma-informed approach. Coordination with mental health professionals. Safety first. Patient control important.

Treatment Principle: Regulate Qi, Calm Shen, Harmonize Liver

Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Lifestyle modifications. Exercise. Meditation. Time management. Work-life balance. Sleep hygiene.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Heart and Kidney, Nourish marrow, Clear Phlegm if present
Primary Acupuncture Points: GV20, Sishencong (EX-HN1), HT7, KI3, ST36, ST40

Treatment Principle: Tonify Lung Qi, Open chest, Support Wei Qi and Po

Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Normal grieving process respected. Support groups. Counseling if complicated grief. Physical activity. Breathing exercises.

Treatment Principle: Calm Shen, Reduce cravings, Support willpower, Detoxify
Primary Acupuncture Points: Ear Shenmen, Sympathetic, Lung points; HT7, PC6, LI4, ST36
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 2-3x per week during cessation; then weekly for 8-12 weeks
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Individualized; may include calming formulas
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Auricular / Ear, Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Part of comprehensive program. Behavioral support essential. Address triggers. Nicotine replacement if appropriate. Auricular seeds between sessions.

Treatment Principle: Soothe Liver, Calm Shen, Resolve Phlegm obstructing Heart
Primary Acupuncture Points: HT7, PC6, LV3, ST40, CV17, GV20, Yintang (EX-HN3)

Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Head & Face (Front View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)

Treatment Principle: Soothe Liver, Move Qi, Regulate menstruation
Primary Acupuncture Points: LV3, LV14, PC6, SP6, GB34, CV6
Treatment Frequency & Duration: Weekly throughout cycle, increase to 2x per week in luteal phase
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Xiao Yao San (逍遥散)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Start treatment 7-10 days before period. Stress management. Regular exercise. Dietary adjustments.

Treatment Principle: Warm meridians, Move Blood, Stop pain
Primary Acupuncture Points: CV4, SP6, SP8, ST29, LV3, BL32 (with moxa)
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 2x per week in week before period; daily during menstruation if needed
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Wen Jing Tang (温经汤) or Shao Fu Zhu Yu Tang (少腹逐瘀汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Heavy moxa to lower abdomen. Heat pad. Avoid cold foods/drinks. Start preventive treatment before period.

Treatment Principle: Soothe Liver, Move Qi, Regulate cycle
Primary Acupuncture Points: LV3, SP6, CV4, ST29, PC6, LV14
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Xiao Yao San (逍遥散)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Track cycles. Stress management. Regular sleep schedule. May take 3-6 cycles to regulate.

Condition / Diagnosis: Heavy Menstrual Bleeding - Spleen Qi Deficiency
Treatment Principle: Tonify Spleen Qi, Hold Blood, Stop bleeding
Primary Acupuncture Points: SP1, SP6, ST36, CV6, BL20, SP10
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 2x per week throughout cycle; more frequent during period
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Gui Pi Tang (归脾汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Rule out pathology (fibroids, etc.). Iron supplementation may be needed. Moxa to ST36, CV6. Avoid cold/raw foods.

Treatment Principle: Nourish Blood, Tonify Liver and Kidney, Regulate menstruation
Primary Acupuncture Points: SP6, ST36, BL17, BL18, BL20, BL23, CV4, LV3
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Si Wu Tang (四物汤) or Ba Zhen Tang (八珍汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Back & Spine (Back View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Rule out pregnancy, PCOS, thyroid issues. Adequate nutrition essential. Weight restoration if underweight. May take months.

Treatment Principle: Nourish Kidney Yin, Clear deficiency Heat, Calm Shen
Primary Acupuncture Points: KI3, KI6, HT6, SP6, LV3, CV4, GV20
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Zhi Bai Di Huang Wan (知柏地黄丸) or Liu Wei Di Huang Wan (六味地黄丸)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Cooling foods. Stress management. Exercise. Sleep hygiene. May need long-term treatment. Coordinate with MD.

Treatment Principle: Regulate menstruation, Nourish Blood, Warm Uterus, Support Kidney
Primary Acupuncture Points: CV4, SP6, ST29, KI3, BL23, ST36, PC6 (cycle-specific points)
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 1x per week continuously, adjusting points based on cycle phase
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Cycle-specific formulas; commonly includes Si Wu Tang (四物汤), Ba Zhen Tang (八珍汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Both partners should be treated if possible. Lifestyle: no smoking/excess alcohol, healthy weight, stress management. May take 3-6 months.

Treatment Principle: Resolve Phlegm-Damp, Invigorate Blood, Regulate menstruation
Primary Acupuncture Points: SP6, SP9, ST40, CV4, ST29, ST36, CV12, LV3
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Cang Fu Dao Tan Wan (苍附导痰丸) + modifications
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Weight loss if overweight crucial. Low GI diet. Exercise. Medical coordination for metabolic issues. Long-term condition.

Treatment Principle: Harmonize Stomach, Descend Qi, Stop nausea
Primary Acupuncture Points: PC6, ST36, CV12, SP4, KI21
Treatment Frequency & Duration: As needed; can be daily if severe
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Xiao Ban Xia Tang (小半夏汤) - use with caution; ginger safe
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: PC6 wrist bands. Small frequent meals. Ginger. Rule out hyperemesis. Usually improves by 12-14 weeks.

Treatment Principle: Warm meridians, Encourage fetal movement
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL67 (with moxa)
Treatment Frequency & Duration: Daily moxa 15-20 min per side, weeks 34-37
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: None typically
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Back View), Foot (Sole/Bottom View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Most effective 34-36 weeks. Patient can do at home. Coordinate with midwife/OB. Success rate varies. Stop if baby turns.

Treatment Principle: Ripen cervix, Tonify Qi, Prepare for labor
Primary Acupuncture Points: LI4, SP6, BL60, BL67, BL32
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Generally none; red raspberry leaf tea
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Leg (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Only after 37 weeks. Gentle treatment. Contraindicated if placenta previa or high-risk pregnancy. Coordinate with care provider.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Qi and Blood, Promote lactation, Restore body
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, CV6, CV12, BL20, GB21, SI1 (if lactation issues)
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Sheng Hua Tang (生化汤) first 2 weeks; Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang (补中益气汤) ongoing
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Rest essential. Nutritious warm foods. Help with baby care. Moxa to CV6. Support for mood issues. Can start week 2-3 postpartum.

Treatment Principle: Clear Heat, Resolve Dampness, Promote urination
Primary Acupuncture Points: CV3, BL28, SP9, SP6, LI11, ST28
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 2-3x per week for 2-3 weeks; may need antibiotics
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Ba Zheng San (八正散)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Increase water intake. Cranberry. Hygiene. Rule out resistance - may need antibiotics. Recurrent UTI needs medical workup.

Treatment Principle: Tonify and Warm Kidney Yang, Consolidate lower jiao
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL23, CV4, KI3, BL28, SP6 (with moxa)
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Jin Gui Shen Qi Wan (金匮肾气丸) or Suo Quan Wan (缩泉丸)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Moxa essential. Avoid cold foods/drinks. Kegel exercises. Rule out prostate issues in men, pelvic floor in women.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Spleen and Kidney, Consolidate, Raise Qi
Primary Acupuncture Points: CV4, CV6, BL23, BL20, ST36, SP6, BL28, GV20
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang (补中益气汤) + Jin Suo Gu Jing Wan (金锁固精丸)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Pelvic floor physical therapy. Kegel exercises. Bladder training. Moxa to CV4, BL23. Rule out serious pathology.

Treatment Principle: Clear Heat, Resolve Dampness, Promote urination, Expel stones
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL23, BL28, CV3, SP9, KI3, GB25

Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Back & Spine (Back View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front)

Treatment Principle: Tonify Kidney, Support function, Regulate fluids
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL23, KI3, CV4, ST36, SP6, BL20

Treatment Principle: Move Qi and Blood, Resolve stagnation, Promote urination

Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Medical monitoring. PSA tests. Rule out malignancy. Saw palmetto. Lifestyle: limit alcohol/caffeine before bed.

Treatment Principle: Nourish Kidney Yin, Clear deficiency Heat, Calm urgency
Primary Acupuncture Points: KI3, CV3, SP6, BL28, BL23, ST28
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Individualized; commonly Liu Wei Di Huang Wan (六味地黄丸) + modifications

Clinical Recommendations & Notes: IC diet essential. Avoid triggers. Stress management. Pelvic floor PT. Coordinate with urologist. Challenging condition.

Treatment Principle: Expel Wind, Clear Heat, Resolve Dampness, Cool Blood
Primary Acupuncture Points: LI11, SP10, BL40, SP6, GB20, LI4

Treatment Principle: Cool Blood, Nourish Yin, Resolve toxicity, Moisten skin
Primary Acupuncture Points: LI11, SP10, LV3, SP6, BL40, BL17
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Liang Xue Xiao Feng Tang (凉血消风汤) or Qing Ying Tang (清营汤)

Treatment Principle: Clear Heat, Resolve Dampness, Cool Blood

Treatment Principle: Expel Wind, Clear Heat, Cool Blood, Stop itching
Primary Acupuncture Points: LI11, GB20, LI4, SP10, SP6, BL40
Treatment Frequency & Duration: Acute: 2-3x per week until resolved; Chronic: 2x per week for 8-12 weeks
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Xiao Feng San (消风散)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View), Head & Neck (Side View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Identify and avoid triggers. Antihistamines may be needed. Cool compresses. Stress reduction. Rule out food allergies.

Treatment Principle: Clear Heat, Nourish Yin, Cool Blood, Harmonize Stomach
Primary Acupuncture Points: LI4, LI11, ST44, SP10, KI3, LV3

Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Avoid triggers: hot drinks, spicy food, alcohol, extreme temps, stress. Gentle skin care. Sunscreen. May need prolonged care.

Condition / Diagnosis: Shingles (Herpes Zoster) - Damp-Heat with Fire Toxin
Treatment Principle: Clear Heat and toxins, Resolve Dampness, Stop pain, Nourish Yin recovery
Primary Acupuncture Points: Surrounding points along affected dermatome, GB34, LI4, LI11, SP6, BL40
Treatment Frequency & Duration: Acute: daily if possible for 7-10 days; Post-herpetic: 2x per week for 8-12 weeks
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Long Dan Xie Gan Tang (龙胆泻肝汤) acute; Yin-nourishing formulas for recovery
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Area-specific per dermatome affected
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Start treatment immediately at onset. Antivirals within 72 hours essential. Surrounding needling, not into lesions. Post-herpetic neuralgia challenging.

Treatment Principle: Nourish Liver Blood, Tonify Kidney, Invigorate scalp
Primary Acupuncture Points: GV20, BL18, BL23, LV3, LV8, GB20, local scalp points
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Qi Bao Mei Ran Dan (七宝美髯丹) or Shou Wu Pian (首乌片)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Face (Front View), Head & Neck (Side View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Rule out medical causes. Nutrition important. Stress management. Scalp massage. Results take months. Not effective for all types.

Treatment Principle: Nourish Liver-Kidney, Invigorate Blood, Dispel Wind
Primary Acupuncture Points: LV3, KI3, BL18, BL23, SP10, SP6, local edge points
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Bai Bo Qu Feng Wan (白驳祛风丸) or individualized formulas
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Area-specific to affected regions
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Manage expectations - results limited and slow. Sunscreen on affected areas. Stress reduction. May combine with phototherapy. Long-term condition.

Treatment Principle: Expel Wind, Invigorate channels, Restore facial function
Primary Acupuncture Points: LI4, ST6, ST7, GB20, local face points (ST2, ST4, GB14, BL2, etc.)
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 3-5x per week in first 2 weeks; then 2-3x per week for 8-12 weeks
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Qian Zheng San (牵正散)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Face (Front View), Head & Neck (Side View), Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Start immediately. Protect eye. Facial exercises. Warm compresses. Steroids within 72 hours. Best prognosis if treated early. Avoid cold wind.

Treatment Principle: Invigorate Blood, Open channels, Restore function, Resolve Phlegm
Primary Acupuncture Points: GV20, GB34, ST36, LI4, LI11, SP6, affected limb points, scalp acupuncture
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 3-5x per week initially; long-term 2x per week
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Bu Yang Huan Wu Tang (补阳还五汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Master Template (Full Body Fallback) - affected side focus
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Medical clearance essential. Start 2-4 weeks post-stroke when stable. Physical/occupational therapy crucial. Earlier treatment better outcome. Long-term commitment.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Spleen-Kidney, Nourish Liver-Kidney, Support function
Primary Acupuncture Points: Individualized based on symptoms; commonly ST36, SP6, BL23, GV20, GB34
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Individualized formulas
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Master Template (Full Body Fallback)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Supportive care only. Medical management essential. Symptom-specific treatment. Stress reduction. Avoid overheating. Regular schedule.

Treatment Principle: Nourish Liver-Kidney, Extinguish Wind, Support movement
Primary Acupuncture Points: LV3, GB34, KI3, GV20, GB20, LI4, ST36, scalp points
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Tian Ma Gou Teng Yin (天麻钩藤饮) + modifications
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Face (Front View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Supportive care only. Medical management essential. May help with tremor, rigidity. Exercise important. Regular treatment schedule.

Treatment Principle: Extinguish Wind, Nourish Liver-Kidney, Calm tremor
Primary Acupuncture Points: LV3, GB34, KI3, GV20, LI4, HT7, PC6
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 2x per week for 8-12 weeks initial; then maintenance
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Tian Ma Gou Teng Yin (天麻钩藤饮)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Head & Face (Front View), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Arm (Yang Meridians / Outer View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Avoid caffeine. Stress management. Beta-blockers may be needed. Variable results. Trial worth attempting.

Treatment Principle: Resolve Phlegm-Dampness, Descend Qi, Harmonize middle jiao
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST40, SP9, PC6, CV12, ST36, GB20, GV20

Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Rule out serious causes (BPPV, Menieres, CVA). Low salt if Menieres. PC6 can help nausea. Epley maneuver if BPPV.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Spleen-Kidney, Generate fluids, Regulate glucose
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, CV12, BL20, BL23, KI3, CV4
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Liu Wei Di Huang Wan (六味地黄丸) + modifications
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Adjunct only - medication essential. Diet and exercise crucial. Monitor blood sugar. Prevent complications. Medical coordination mandatory.

Treatment Principle: Nourish Yin, Clear Heat, Calm Liver, Soften hardness
Primary Acupuncture Points: KI3, HT7, LV3, PC6, ST9, CV22, ST36
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 1-2x per week as adjunct to medical treatment
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Individualized; often Yin-nourishing + sedating herbs
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Arm (Yin Meridians / Inner View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Medical management essential. Avoid iodine excess. Stress management. Monitor thyroid levels. Coordinate with endocrinologist.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Spleen-Kidney Yang, Warm meridians, Resolve Phlegm
Primary Acupuncture Points: CV4, CV6, ST36, BL20, BL23, ST9, ST40 (with moxa)
Treatment Frequency & Duration: 1-2x per week as adjunct to thyroid medication
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Jin Gui Shen Qi Wan (金匮肾气丸) + modifications
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Back & Spine (Back View), Leg & Thigh (Front View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Thyroid hormone replacement essential. Moxa to CV4, CV6. Support energy. Monitor thyroid levels. Medical coordination mandatory.

Treatment Principle: Resolve Phlegm-Dampness, Tonify Spleen, Move Blood, Regulate
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP9, SP6, ST40, CV12, CV9, ST25
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Er Chen Tang (二陈汤) + Dan Shen (丹参) or Shan Zha (山楂)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Leg & Thigh (Front View)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Lifestyle crucial: diet, exercise, weight loss. Stress management. May need medications. Long-term condition requiring commitment.

Treatment Principle: Resolve Phlegm, Invigorate Blood, Tonify Spleen, Move stagnation
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, SP9, ST40, LV3, CV12, BL20
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Ze Xie Tang (泽泻汤) or formulas with Shan Zha (山楂), Dan Shen (丹参)

Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Diet essential: low saturated fat, high fiber. Exercise. Weight loss if needed. May need statins. Monitor lipids. Lifestyle primary.

Treatment Principle: Resolve Phlegm-Dampness, Tonify Spleen, Move Qi, Promote metabolism
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, SP9, ST40, CV9, ST25, CV12

Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Realistic expectations. Diet and exercise primary. Acupuncture supportive. Behavioral changes essential. Long-term commitment. Auricular points helpful.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Qi, Nourish Blood, Support Spleen and Kidney, Calm Shen
Primary Acupuncture Points: ST36, SP6, CV6, BL20, BL23, HT7, GV20, PC6
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang (补中益气汤) or Ba Zhen Tang (八珍汤)
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV), Back & Spine (Back View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Pacing activities. Gentle gradual exercise. Sleep hygiene. Stress management. Nutrition. Rule out other causes. Challenging condition.

Treatment Principle: Tonify Kidney Yang, Support adrenal function, Warm meridians
Primary Acupuncture Points: BL23, CV4, CV6, ST36, KI3, GV4 (with moxa)
Herbal Pharmacopeia Formula: Jin Gui Shen Qi Wan (金匮肾气丸) - coordinate with MD
Relevant Body Parts / Figures: Back & Spine (Back View), Chest & Upper Abdomen (Front), Leg (Inner View - SP/KI/LV)
Clinical Recommendations & Notes: Supportive only. Steroid replacement essential and life-saving. Medical management mandatory. Stress dose steroids when ill. Medical coordination crucial.
